title: What are the differences between relative and absolute positioning in CSS?
content: `position: relative` offsets an element from its normal position without removing it from the document flow. `position: absolute` removes the element from the flow and positions it relative to the nearest positioned ancestor (or viewport if none).
explanation: Relative positioning keeps the element in the flow; absolute positioning takes it out and anchors to a positioned parent.

options.text: `relative`: offsets in flow; `absolute`: removed from flow, relative to positioned ancestor
`absolute` is always relative to the body

title: What is the CSS Box Model?
content: The CSS Box Model describes the structure of every HTML element as consisting of content, padding, border, and margin.
explanation: Understanding the box model is essential for accurate layout calculations. `box-sizing: border-box` includes padding and border in width/height.
sampleAnswers: The CSS Box Model consists of four layers: content (text/image), padding (inside border), border, and margin (outside border).
By default, `width` and `height` apply only to content. Use `box-sizing: border-box` to include padding and border in sizing.

title: How do you specify units in CSS? What are the different types?
content: CSS units include absolute (px, pt, cm) and relative (em, rem, %, vw, vh) units for defining lengths, sizes, and spacing.
explanation: Relative units scale with context (e.g., `em` with font-size, `vw` with viewport width); absolute units are fixed.

options.text: Absolute: px, pt, cm; Relative: em, rem, %, vw, vh
All units behave the same across devices

title: Which unit would you prefer among px, em, %, or rem and why?
content: `px` gives precise control; `em` is relative to parent font-size; `%` is relative to parent size; `rem` is relative to root font-size and avoids compounding.
explanation: `rem` is preferred for scalability and accessibility; `px` for fixed sizes; avoid `em` for layout due to compounding.
sampleAnswers: `rem` is best for consistent scaling (relative to root font-size). `px` is fine for borders or fixed elements. Avoid `em` in layout to prevent nesting issues.
Use `%` for fluid containers, `vw`/`vh` for full-viewport elements, and `rem` for typography and spacing.

title: What is a pseudo-element? What is a pseudo-class?
content: Pseudo-elements (`::before`, `::first-line`) style parts of an element. Pseudo-classes (`:hover`, `:nth-child`) style elements in specific states.
explanation: Pseudo-elements create virtual content; pseudo-classes respond to user interaction or structural position.

options.text: Pseudo-elements: virtual parts (e.g., ::before); Pseudo-classes: element states (e.g., :hover)

title: Explain the CSS Box Model and its components.
content: The Box Model includes: content (actual text/image), padding (space inside border), border (edge around padding), and margin (space outside border).
explanation: Total width = content width + padding + border + margin. Use `box-sizing: border-box` to simplify sizing.
sampleAnswers: The Box Model has four layers: content (where text/images go), padding (inner spacing), border (visible edge), and margin (outer spacing).
By default, setting `width: 100px` means content is 100px. With `box-sizing: border-box`, the entire element (including padding/border) is 100px.

title: How do you tell the browser to render layout in different box models?
content: Use the `box-sizing` property: `content-box` (default) or `border-box` (includes padding/border in width/height).
explanation: `box-sizing: border-box` is preferred in modern CSS for predictable sizing.

options.text: `content-box`: width = content only; `border-box`: width = content + padding + border

title: What is the difference between border-box and content-box?
content: `content-box` (default): width/height apply to content only. `border-box`: width/height include content, padding, and border.
explanation: `border-box` prevents layout shifts when adding padding/border, making responsive design easier.

options.text: `content-box`: width excludes padding/border; `border-box`: width includes them

title: Explain the meaning of CSS length units like cm, em, in, mm, pc, pt, px.
content: Absolute units: `cm` (centimeters), `in` (inches), `mm` (millimeters), `pc` (picas), `pt` (points), `px` (pixels). Relative: `em` (font-size relative).
explanation: Absolute units are fixed; `px` is standard for screens. `em` scales with font-size, useful for accessibility.
sampleAnswers: `px` is 1/96th of an inch—standard for screen design. `em` equals the current font-size (e.g., 16px default → 1em = 16px).
Avoid `pt`, `pc`, `in` for web—they’re print units. Use `px` for borders, `rem`/`em` for text, `%`/`vw` for responsive layouts.

title: How would you select <a> elements whose href starts with 'https', ends with '.pdf', or contains 'css'?
content: Use attribute selectors: `a[href^='https']`, `a[href$='.pdf']`, `a[href*='css']`.
explanation: Attribute selectors enable precise targeting based on HTML attribute values without extra classes.

options.text: Only class selectors can target links

title: What is the purpose of the box-sizing property?
content: `box-sizing` controls how an element’s total width and height are calculated—whether padding and border are included.
explanation: `border-box` simplifies layout by making width/height include padding and border, preventing overflow issues.
sampleAnswers: `box-sizing: border-box` ensures that when you set `width: 100px`, the element—including padding and border—is exactly 100px wide.
It’s a best practice to apply `*, *::before, *::after { box-sizing: border-box; }` globally for consistent sizing.

title: What is the difference between RGBa, HEX, and HSLa color formats?
content: `RGBa`: red/green/blue/alpha (0–255 or %). `HEX`: #RRGGBB or #RGB. `HSLa`: hue (0–360), saturation (%), lightness (%), alpha.
explanation: HSLa is more intuitive for designers; RGBa and HEX are widely supported. All support alpha transparency.

options.text: HEX supports alpha; RGBa does not

title: What is a CSS preprocessor?
content: A CSS preprocessor (Sass, LESS, Stylus) extends CSS with variables, nesting, mixins, and functions, compiling to standard CSS.
explanation: Preprocessors improve maintainability and enable logic-like features (variables, loops) not native to CSS.
sampleAnswers: Sass allows variables (`$primary: #333;`), nesting, and mixins—compiled to standard CSS for browser compatibility.
Preprocessors reduce repetition, enable modular architecture, and support math operations (e.g., `width: 100% / 3;`).

title: What is the difference between 'resetting' and 'normalizing' CSS?
content: Resetting removes all default browser styles. Normalizing makes styles consistent across browsers while preserving useful defaults.
explanation: Normalize.css is preferred for modern projects—it fixes browser inconsistencies without stripping all defaults.

options.text: Reset: removes all styles; Normalize: preserves useful defaults, fixes inconsistencies

title: Explain CSS Block Formatting Context (BFC).
content: A BFC is an isolated rendering area where block-level boxes are laid out without affecting outside elements. Created by `overflow: hidden`, `float`, `display: flow-root`, etc.
explanation: BFCs prevent margin collapse and contain floated children—essential for complex layouts.
sampleAnswers: A BFC isolates layout: margins don’t collapse with outside elements, and floated children are contained. Create one with `overflow: hidden` or `display: flow-root`.
Use BFC to fix common issues: parent height collapse with floats, or unwanted margin merging between adjacent blocks.

title: What is the float property and what does it do?
content: `float` places an element to the left or right of its container, allowing text and inline elements to wrap around it.
explanation: Floats were used for layouts before Flexbox/Grid but are now mainly for text wrapping (e.g., images in articles).
sampleAnswers: `float: left` moves an element to the left, with content wrapping on the right. Common for image captions in text.
Floats take elements out of normal flow—use `clear` or BFC to manage layout consequences.

title: Describe the clear property in CSS.
content: `clear` specifies which sides of an element cannot have floating elements, preventing overlap.
explanation: `clear: both` forces an element below all floated siblings—essential for footer placement after floated columns.

options.text: `clear: left` prevents left floats; `clear: right` prevents right floats; `clear: both` prevents both

title: Explain the purpose of clearing floats in CSS.
content: Clearing floats ensures that non-floated elements (like footers) appear below floated content instead of wrapping beside it.
explanation: Without clearing, containers collapse and subsequent elements wrap around floats—`clear` or modern layout methods fix this.
sampleAnswers: Use `clear: both` on a footer to ensure it appears below floated sidebars. Modern alternative: use Flexbox/Grid instead of floats for layout.
The clearfix hack (`overflow: hidden` or `::after { clear: both }`) contains floats within a parent container.

title: What is a clearfix in CSS?
content: A clearfix is a technique to contain floated children within a parent container, preventing height collapse.
explanation: Modern solution: `display: flow-root` creates a BFC. Legacy: `::after { content: ''; clear: both; }`.
sampleAnswers: A clearfix forces a parent to wrap floated children. Modern method: `parent { display: flow-root; }`. Legacy: use a `::after` pseudo-element with `clear: both`.
Without clearfix, a parent with only floated children has zero height—clearfix fixes this layout issue.

title: Does `overflow: hidden` create a new block formatting context?
content: Yes. `overflow: hidden` (and any non-`visible` overflow value) creates a new Block Formatting Context (BFC).
explanation: This is why `overflow: hidden` contains floats and prevents margin collapse—it creates a new BFC.
